subject: Support inband write for PELS from HB to bmc
commitMessage:
Support inband write for PELS from HB to bmc

also do not delete the temporary file after calling
DBus api storePel. The file will be deleted by pel daemon
after processing

Signed-off-by: George Liu <liuxiwei@inspur.com>
Change-Id: I2d38fc42a2d7127eff22983ca83091d323736e2c

code tested good
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as d37b49592012040834b26266e5bf3d9c510cf3e1 by George Liu
which file name does it create?

This code should be improved to be obviously correct. If we must have a named file this needs to use mkostemp() to eliminate the concept of races, and to specify additional flags like O_SYNC. O_WRONLY is a minor restriction over the default O_RDWR that we can ignore to make use of mkostemp(), and additionally the mktemp() family enforce O_CREAT | O_EXCL to make sure the file is unique which eliminates the need for O_TRUNC.

It would be better if storePel() took a file descriptor instead, and then you could use open() with O_TMPFILE with /tmp as the directory and avoid the naming problem altogether.

on the same line with my previous question, the tmpFile gets created with same name every time. that leads to error in the pel files when HB sends down consecutive pels.
pls change the code to use mkstemp as we are doing in the dma write
Ack
Is this not "file open failure" and not seek
Done
Why aren't length and offset off_t? Wouldn't it be better for buffer to be const void *?
this is how it has been designed in the file io and other files. he followed the same. may be we can do that improvement later on which needs a change in all the file types
This is a bit lazy? This isn't a failure, you need to keep moving your write pointer through the buffer (potentially issuing multiple write calls).

Sorry, It is my mistake.
The return value of the write method has only two cases: success (the return value is equal to the number of bytes written) and failure (-1).
Updated.

the return value of write() can be *less* than the length provided as a parameter, so dropping this check isn't the right way to solve it. You need a loop to iterate through the buffer until write() has written all the data in the buffer.
Done
Why do this test again? Why not just call storePel() in the happy case above?
Ack

There wasn't a response to my request to pass a file descriptor here (and through the D-Bus API) instead of the file name. Using a file descriptor is a better representation of the problem generally (removes a lot of the races).

the current DBus method  "Create" accepts a filename. and we are using a filename for pels sent by Phyp as well
supporting a fd as parameter would need change from both the sides which may not be possible immediately
use after move?

Not only that, but there's no guarantee that the dbus call backing storePel() has even completed because we don't wait for a response. This could remove the file before the remote call has even executed, and as we're passing a file name and not a descriptor, the remote daemon will hit an ENOENT.
may be deleting the file can be done by pel daemon?
I have replaced `std::move()` with `fs::path::string`.
We don't need lseek() if we've enforced offset == 0.
Done
Can we come up with a better name for this? It represents the sum of the lengths of data written by prior calls to write().

Ack
Replaced reveiveLen with `writeTotalLength`, What do you think?
If we fail to write , then we return at 314 without closing the file. Should we not close the file at line 309 , irrespective of the status of file Write ?

Ack
Moved it to L: 309
This doesn't work if we've handled partial writes (i.e. executed the body of the while loop above). Check the relationship between length, rc and receiveLen.

Sorry, it is my mistake
Updated
Should we add a error trace if storepel fails.
Ack

You can't remove the file until you know the process handling the D-Bus call via storePel() has opened the file.

This isn't even something you can know currently, so you can't remove the file.

Doing the cleanup in a way that isn't racy is why this needs to be handled via file descriptor passing.
Ack, Removed
This should be ssize_t. Also the method should return ssize_t just like write(), but that's probably a broader problem.
Right, I think I can push a new patch to fix this issue
Ack

We can improve this. With the rework to the write() loop above we can just use one condition. Additionally, we should be casting length to an size_t (and it really should be a size_t or off_t to begin with).

 if (written == static_cast<size_t>(length))
Done

Do we want to delete the PEL file in this case? I feel like we should leave it there for someone to manually collect. We should call the file name out in the log message on std::cerr.

We also need to make pldmd delete the PEL file in the happy case.
Done

how do we delete the temp pel file in good path? can pel daemon delete the file after processing @Mattspinler?
at present we call the "Create" DBus method as bus.call_noreply() and then delete the temp pel file from /tmp. do you think that may lead to situation where pel daemon can get corrupted log? or the log gets deleted before it is processed by you?

I guess I can see a few options:
1) Don't use call_noreply
2) what you suggest here, have the PEL code delete the file, which is fine
3) Make a new D-Bus method to pass a file descriptor instead, which was mentioned earlier

I'm  not sure if this is what was causing the other problem, but I imagine we should probably figure this piece out first.

i choose pel daemon to delete the file after processing. and we will make same change for the Phyp pels as well. if we still see the problem happening, may be we can shift to the new DBus method for using a fd
